Why can‚Äôt one create a circular can network, so that if one device comes unplugged, att devices stay online? Besides the obvious Roborio only has a single can terminal lol

Its not how CAN works. CAN is supposed to have a start and End. You‚Äôd basically create an infinite echo chamber.

Edit: I stand corrected. See below

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T19:03:59.848Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":496,"readers_count":495,"score":114.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"Technologyman00","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25951,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7900, 1792, 1714"},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/2","custom_user_title":"7900, 1792, 1714","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3346286,"name":"Adam Hersh","username":"adhersh","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adhersh/{size}/191423_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-28T15:37:34.178Z","cooked":"

What you‚Äôre describing is commonly referred to as ‚Äústar topology.‚Äù A significant problem with this setup is that connecting all your lines to a single point can alter the intrinsic impedance of the line. In a star configuration, signals encounter a high-impedance termination, essentially an open circuit, which can cause them to reflect down the line and may potentially interfere with the other devices.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T15:37:34.178Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":469,"readers_count":468,"score":93.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"Adam Hersh","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56567,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 4 Alumni, Team 254 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/3","custom_user_title":"Team 4 Alumni, Team 254 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"question","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3346305,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-28T15:48:12.447Z","cooked":"

You‚Äôre talking about a Ring Bus.

Try it out. With careful implementation it might work just fine for your needs. And if it doesn‚Äôt pan out you only need to disconnect one junction to turn it back into a chained bus.

FWIW all CAN devices are wired in parallel and you can create or buy wiring that is agnostic to devices being disconnected. REV CAN wire has a jumper loops to do just this. We even used a length of it for a CAN extension this year.

REV Robotics

SPARK MAX CAN Cable V2 - 2 Pack

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 5.5

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T15:48:54.138Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":411,"readers_count":410,"score":137.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/rev-11-1880/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SPARK MAX CAN Cable V2 - 2 Pack - REV Robotics","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3346345,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-28T16:20:56.679Z","cooked":"

This is absolutely possible. Like stated above this is often called a Star or Bus Topology. You do reduce some aspects of performance, but generally for FRC with the low bandwidth CANBUS we use, its not a huge issue.


The way most people seem to implement this is like the graphic above having a single long path directly from the CRIO (which has a built in 120ohm terminating resistor) to the PDP/PDH (which has a built in 120ohm terminating resistor) or a separate terminating resistor (if you do this, make sure to disable the terminating resistor/move the jumper on your PDP/PDH) . Then you can tap anywhere along that path for all your intermediate devices. The best practice is to keep the lengths of your taps as short as possible (under 1ft for sure, but shorter is better). Both of the teams I‚Äôve worked with in the last few years have used this topology without significant issue, but it will depend on your number of devices, length of taps/stubs, and so on.

As far as connectors, my teams have come to like these level-nut style connectors. The advantage being they are simple to use as long as your strip the correct amount of insulation and you can remove a device without breaking the bus, but you do have to cut your main path to insert them, so this does technically add points of failure to your main bus.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08JPBJDW4/

Previously we‚Äôd also tried these crimp-on splice connectors, which have the advantage of not having to break the main bus to add them, or even remove them. They do seem to be picky about what wire they work best with, and you do risk issue with the crimp not making good contact, but once we had some good wire it liked, we never had that happen to us. I‚Äôd also recommend adding a short (2-3in) piece of can wire on the stub side and use a 2-in 2-out lever-nut connector on that to connect to the device.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07114RK67/

Here is the wire we found that worked great with the splice connectors, just had to twist it ourselves:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00NB3SV6S/
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00NB3U6H0/

A lot of terminology getting mixed up already in this thread. Star, Ring, and Bus topologies are all different things, and are not interchangeable terms.

The CANBus should be, well, a Bus. There are many different ways to achieve that bus topology.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T19:32:08.203Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":225,"readers_count":224,"score":125.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/6","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3346712,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-28T21:09:48.081Z","cooked":"

One thing not obvious is that setting up CAN in a ring is not a dual ring. In a dual ring, data move clockwise on one ring, and counterclockwise on the other. I‚Äôve seen this on fiber networks (where each packet is received and retransmitted to the next neighbor); I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs ever used electrically.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T21:09:48.081Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":42.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":2514,"username":"Lil_Lavery","name":"Sean Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/7","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3346721,"name":"Rocky","username":"Rocky_S","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rocky_s/{size}/220194_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-28T21:16:42.748Z","cooked":"

Always wanted to see this, as it‚Äôs frustrating for 1 snapped CAN wire to leave the whole bot no longer moving and crash the whole code

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T21:17:24.122Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":34.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"Rocky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58611,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3346743,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-28T21:31:20.669Z","cooked":"

Yes, dual ring message passing is absolutely used electrically (industrial Ethernet is one example). But not with CAN. CAN is a broadcast model - every node ‚Äúhears‚Äù every message sent.

As I‚Äôve said before, for standard CAN (without a CANivore) in FRC applications you can pretty much use whatever physical topology you want as long as:

  • you twist CANH and CANL together
  • you have exactly two 120 ohm termination resistors somewhere in the network connected between CANH and CANL
  • you keep the length of the longest connection between any two devices to less than 3 meters
  • you make sure that CANH and CANL are never swapped, open circuited, shorted together, or shorted to something else.

Follow these rules, and you could make a mesh or ring or whatever and it‚Äôll work. The total network is too small to care, reflections are damped out in less than a bit time. That being said, the biggest problem I‚Äôve found with CAN in FRC is connections, which are a whole separate religion that I will not delve into here.

With a CANivore, follow the rules CTRE publishes very carefully. Linear bus topology only, very small or no stubs, still follow the other rules. CAN FD (which is what the CANivore uses) is 10x the speed of CAN and does not tolerate strange topologies.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-03-28T21:31:20.669Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":93.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460464,"topic_slug":"circular-can","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22335,"username":"GeeTwo","name":"Gus Michel II","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/circular-can/460464/9","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3544661,"name":"","username":"Deuro","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/deuro/{size}/176733_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T04:03:53.009Z","cooked":"

Update in 2025: We used a ring topology this year, there was many CAN errors and the sparkmaxes kept failing to update. I unplugged one of the wires and it all works great now. It seems like the ‚Äústandard CAN‚Äù very much does not like to do that.
